channel.title: Pam Finlayson
channel.description: Pam Finlayson (Remarks as Prepared for Delivery)

item.title: In 1982, my husband Grant and I moved from California to Massachusetts, with our newborn son.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: Being a church-going family, we looked for the nearest chapel and soon found ourselves in a congregation led by a clearly bright and capable man, named Mitt Romney.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: I knew Mitt was special from the start.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: We didn't own a dryer, and the day he stopped by to welcome us, I was embarrassed to have laundry hanging all over the house. Mitt wasn't fazed.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: In fact, as we spoke, without a word, he joined me and started helpfully plucking clothes from around the room and folding them.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: By the time Mitt left, not only did I feel welcome, my laundry was done!
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: As Grant and I juggled school, jobs, church and family, we grew to love the Romneys.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: They became role-models and friends, and we were honored when Mitt and Ann regularly trusted us to stay with their five rambunctious - but very loving - sons when they traveled.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: It was when our daughter Kate was born three and a half months early that I fully came to appreciate what a great treasure of friendship we had in Mitt and Ann.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: Kate was so tiny and very sick.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: Her lungs not yet ready to breathe, her heart unstable, and after suffering a severe brain hemorrhage at three days old, she was teetering on the very edge of life.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: As I sat with her in intensive care, consumed with a mother's worry and fear, dear Mitt came to visit and pray with me. As our clergy, he was one of few visitors allowed.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: I will never forget that when he looked down tenderly at my daughter, his eyes filled with tears, and he reached out gently and stroked her tiny back.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: I could tell immediately that he didn't just see a tangle of plastic and tubes; he saw our beautiful little girl, and he was clearly overcome with compassion for her.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: During the many months Kate was hospitalized, the Romneys often cared for our two-year old son, Peter. They treated him like one of their own, even welcoming him to stay the night when needed.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: When Thanksgiving rolled around, Kate was still struggling for life.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: Brain surgery was scheduled, and the holiday was the furthest thing from our minds.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: I opened my door to find Mitt and his boys, arms loaded with a Thanksgiving feast.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: Of course we were overcome. When I called to thank Ann, she sweetly confessed it had been Mitt's idea, that most of the cooking and chopping had been done by him.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: She and the boys had just happily pitched in.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: Eventually we moved from Boston. Our daughter Kate grew into an amazing girl of faith and love.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: But complications of her birth remained with her, and after 26 years of both miracles and struggle, she passed away just a year and a half ago.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: In the midst of making the final decision to run for President ­ which had to be the most difficult of their lives ­ when they heard of Kate's passing, both Mitt and Ann paused, to personally reach out to extend us sympathy, and express their love.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: It seems to me when it comes to loving our neighbor, we can talk about it, or we can live it.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: The Romney's live it every single day.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: When the world looks at Mitt Romney, they see him as the founder of a successful business, the leader of the Olympics, or a Governor.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: When I see Mitt, I know him to be a loving father, man of faith and caring and compassionate friend.
item.author: Pam Finlayson

item.title: It is with great excitement and a renewed hope, to know that our country will be blessed as it is led by a man who is not only so accomplished and capable, but who has devoted his entire life quietly serving others. That man is Mitt Romney.
item.author: Pam Finlayson
